overview: Failure of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems may be acutely life threatening if adequate intervention is not forthcoming. Hence effective management of such cases will save lives that would otherwise be lost.  This subject provides the opportunity to gain a thorough understanding of the physiology and pathophysiology of these systems. Additionally, this subject covers foundational topics such as fluid therapy, shock and acid-base analysis. Understanding of these topics is highly advantageous if emergency patients are to be successfully managed. Students will build on knowledge that was acquired as an undergraduate and develop a deeper understanding and improved clinical confidence in these areas. A good understanding of this subject is highly desirable before continuing with further study in this course.
intended learning outcomes: Recall the physiological principles underlying regulation of body fluid dynamics; oxygen delivery; and regulation of cardiovascular and respiratory homeostasis.
Relate the clinical signs of cardiovascular and respiratory emergencies to the underlying pathophysiology.
Interpret clinical signs and diagnostic tests as they apply to assessment of patents that have shock, cardiac failure or respiratory compromise.
Interpret clinical and diagnostic findings in order to identify sound management plans for patients that have electrolyte imbalances; cardiovascular compromise; and/or respiratory compromise.
Recall the mechanism of action of medications used for cardiovascular and respiratory emergencies.

necessary pre-requisite: This subject is not available for students admitted in any other courses.
additional pre-requisite: Admission into the GC-SAECC Graduate Certificate in Small Animal Emergency and Critical Care

assessments.description: Self-assessment by multiple choice questions, 10 MCQ for each of 10 tutorials, takes 20 minutes - following each tutorial and one prior to subject completion. 200 minutes (total)
50 MCQ open book examination, during exam week. 100 minutes. Hurdle requirement:. To pass this examination, a minimum mark of 70% is required.
Interpretation of 25 case studies assessed by structured questions pertaining to each case - 5 MCQ per case. 250 minutes (total)

Prescribed texts: Small Animal Critical Care Medicine 2 nd Ed. By Silverstein and Hopper.
Students will be provided with additional reading material online.
